questions.text: A post-operative patient who is immobilized develops sudden onset severe calf pain. What is the next investigation to be done? ( FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Duplex USG

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • The correct answer is duplex ultrasound (USG). The clinical picture suggests deep vein thrombosis (DVT), which is a common complication in immobilized, post-operative patients.
  • • Duplex ultrasound is the investigation of choice for diagnosing DVT as it combines traditional ultrasound and Doppler ultrasound to visualize blood flow and identify any thrombus in the veins.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. CT angiography: This is primarily used for pulmonary embolism, not for initial evaluation of suspected DVT.
  • • Option A. CT angiography:
  • • Option C. X-ray: This is not useful for diagnosing DVT, as it does not provide information about the veins or blood flow.
  • • Option C. X-ray:
  • • Option D. MRI: While MRI can visualize DVT, it is not the first-line investigation due to higher cost, longer procedure time, and less availability compared to duplex ultrasound.
  • • Option D. MRI:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For post-operative, immobilized patients with sudden onset severe calf pain, suggesting DVT, the next investigation should be a duplex ultrasound, which effectively visualizes the veins and assesses blood flow to confirm the diagnosis. ​

questions.text: An HIV patient presents with breathlessness and cough. His recent CD4 count was less than 200 and the patient’s chest X-ray is shown. BAL was done and reports are pending. What is the likely diagnosis and treatment? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Pneumocystis jiroveci; Cotrimoxazole

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In an HIV patient with a CD4 count less than 200, presenting with breathlessness and bilateral infiltrates on chest X-ray, the likely diagnosis is Pneumocystis jiroveci pneumonia (PJP), and the treatment of choice is cotrimoxazole.

questions.text: Which is the characteristic pattern seen in Brown-Sequard syndrome? (NEET PG 2018)

options.label: A
options.text: Contralateral loss of joint sense and position

options.label: C
options.text: Ipsilateral loss of complete sensory functions

questions.correct_answer: B. Contralateral loss of pain sensation
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Contralateral loss of pain sensation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In Brown-Sequard syndrome, the characteristic neurological pattern includes ipsilateral motor weakness and proprioceptive loss, alongside contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation, due to a lateral hemisection of the spinal cord.

questions.text: A child was diagnosed to have CFTR gene mutations. What is the defective channel? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Cl

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Mutations in the CFTR gene lead to defective chloride channels, which are responsible for the thick, sticky mucus characteristic of cystic fibrosis.

questions.text: Which among the following is the most severe manifestation of CKD? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Hyperkalemia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hyperkalemia in CKD patients is a critical condition that requires immediate medical attention due to its potential to cause fatal cardiac disturbances. Always prioritize the management of hyperkalemia in CKD patients to prevent cardiac complications.

questions.text: Metabolic acidosis with normal anion gap is seen in all except? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Salicylate poisoning.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman with a recent type B aortic dissection presents with abdominal pain and lower limb ischemia with diminished femoral and popliteal pulses. What is the most appropriate next step?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Repair the descending aorta

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Enalaprilat: Although used for blood pressure control, it doesn't address the underlying issue of malperfusion.
  • • Option A. Enalaprilat:
  • • Option B. Increasing nitroprusside: May help with blood pressure control but doesn't solve the urgent need for revascularization.
  • • Option B. Increasing nitroprusside:
  • • Option D. Switching to amlodipine: Not appropriate in an acute setting requiring immediate intervention.
  • • Option D. Switching to amlodipine:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Recognize the signs of complicated type B aortic dissection (malperfusion syndromes) and the need for immediate surgical/endovascular repair.

questions.text: 60-year-old obese lady underwent cholecystectomy. After 3 days she develops respiratory distress. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Pulmonary embolism

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • The patient, an obese post-operative case following cholecystectomy, presents with respiratory distress three days after surgery. This is highly suggestive of a pulmonary embolism, particularly in the context of immobilization and the hypercoagulable state following surgery. Pulmonary embolism is a common and serious complication of deep vein thrombosis (DVT), which can occur due to immobilization and endothelial injury during surgery.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Air embolism: This is less likely in this scenario as it typically occurs immediately during or after surgical procedures involving vascular access.
  • • Option B. Air embolism:
  • • Option C. Atelectasis: While atelectasis can cause respiratory distress post-operatively, it typically does not cause sudden severe symptoms three days post-op.
  • • Option C. Atelectasis:
  • • Option D. Myocardial Infarction: Although possible, the context of recent surgery and immobilization makes pulmonary embolism a more likely diagnosis.
  • • Option D. Myocardial Infarction:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In post-operative patients, particularly those who are obese and immobilized, the development of sudden respiratory distress should raise suspicion for pulmonary embolism due to the increased risk of deep vein thrombosis and subsequent embolization. Prompt diagnosis and management are crucial.
  • ➤ Note - The rule of threes (in Immobilization) whenever the patient is immobilized for more than 72 hours/ >3 days in the last 3 months that is called significant immobilization and that increases the risk of DVT and pulmonary embolism.
  • ➤ Note -

questions.text: An 11-year-old child who weighs 26 kg with a history of streptococcal pharyngitis presents to you with fever and arthralgia. There is no past history of rheumatic heart disease or features of carditis or valvular disease. How often is benzathine penicillin recommended for prophylaxis of rheumatic heart disease? (Neet pg 2022)

options.label: A
options.text: 600000 IU Once in 3 weeks for 5 years

options.label: B
options.text: 600000 IU Once in 3 weeks for 10 years

options.label: C
options.text: 1200000 IU Once in 3 weeks for 10 years

options.label: D
options.text: 1200000 IU Once in 3 weeks for life

questions.correct_answer: B. 600000 IU Once in 3 weeks for 10 years
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For an 11-year-old child weighing 26 kg with a history of streptococcal pharyngitis and no carditis or valvulitis, benzathine penicillin G prophylaxis should be administered at a dose of 600,000 IU every 3 weeks for a duration of 10 years (until the child turns 21 years old).

questions.text: A patient with a history of TB presents with hemoptysis. X-ray is shown. What is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Aspergilloma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Aspergilloma is a fungal infection that commonly occurs in pre-existing lung cavities from conditions such as tuberculosis. It presents as a cavity with a fungal ball inside and can cause hemoptysis, which may be severe.

questions.text: In which electrolyte abnormality is a sine wave pattern observed on ECG? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Hyperkalemia

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Hyperkalemia significantly alters cardiac electrophysiology, particularly at high serum potassium levels. The ECG changes progress in severity as potassium levels rise:
  • • Hyperkalemia
  • • Tall, tented T waves: Early manifestation due to accelerated repolarization. QRS prolongation: Due to slowed conduction. Sine wave pattern: Seen in severe hyperkalemia as QRS complexes merge with T waves, a pre-terminal finding leading to ventricular fibrillation or asystole.
  • • Tall, tented T waves: Early manifestation due to accelerated repolarization.
  • • Tall, tented T waves:
  • • QRS prolongation: Due to slowed conduction.
  • • QRS prolongation:
  • • Sine wave pattern: Seen in severe hyperkalemia as QRS complexes merge with T waves, a pre-terminal finding leading to ventricular fibrillation or asystole.
  • • Sine wave pattern:
  • • Prompt treatment of hyperkalemia is critical to prevent life-threatening arrhythmias.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Hypokalemia: Incorrect because hypokalemia causes prolonged QT interval, U waves, and pseudo P pulmonale, not a sine wave pattern.
  • • Option A. Hypokalemia:
  • • Option C. Hypocalcemia: Incorrect because hypocalcemia causes prolonged QT interval due to an elongated ST segment, not a sine wave pattern.
  • • Option C. Hypocalcemia:
  • • Option D. Hypercalcemia: Incorrect because hypercalcemia leads to a shortened QT interval and ST segment but does not produce sine wave patterns on ECG.
  • • Option D. Hypercalcemia:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A sine wave pattern on ECG is a hallmark of severe hyperkalemia and indicates imminent risk of ventricular arrhythmias and cardiac arrest. Rapid intervention with calcium gluconate, insulin with glucose, and potassium-lowering therapies is essential to stabilize cardiac conduction and prevent mortality.

questions.text: Patient has problems in doing heel to shin test and repeatedly misses, and he has tremors in his hands. What is the likely site of lesion?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Cerebellum

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • The heel-to-shin test is a classic test for cerebellar function, and difficulty or inaccuracy in performing this test indicates cerebellar dysfunction.
  • • Additionally, the presence of tremors, particularly intention tremors, is characteristic of cerebellar lesions.
  • • Cerebellar dysfunction can also present with other signs such as dysdiadochokinesia (difficulty with rapid alternating movements), dysmetria (inability to judge distance or scale), nystagmus, and ataxia (uncoordinated movement).
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Caudate: Lesions in the caudate nucleus are associated with chorea, characterized by involuntary, irregular, and unpredictable movements.
  • • Option B. Caudate:
  • • chorea,
  • • Option C. Globus pallidus: Lesions here typically result in dystonia and rigidity, not tremors or difficulty with the heel-to-shin test.
  • • Option C. Globus pallidus:
  • • dystonia
  • • Option D. Pyramidal tract: Lesions in the pyramidal tract lead to spasticity, increased muscle tone, and exaggerated deep tendon reflexes, not the symptoms described in this patient.
  • • Option D. Pyramidal tract:
  • • spasticity,

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cerebellar lesions are indicated by difficulties with coordination tests such as the heel-to-shin test, presence of intention tremors, and other signs of ataxia. Recognizing these features helps in localizing the lesion to the cerebellum.

questions.text: A mutation in the gene for aquaporin channels leading to impaired sweat gland function and heat intolerance is most likely to result in which of the following conditions? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Hypohidrotic Ectodermal Dysplasia

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Hypohidrotic ectodermal dysplasia is associated with mutations in various genes, including those encoding aquaporin channels. Aquaporins, specifically involved in sweat gland function, play a role in sweat production. Mutations leading to impaired aquaporin function result in decreased or absent sweat production, leading to heat intolerance. This condition can also present with other ectodermal abnormalities, such as sparse hair and hypodontia.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Liddle's syndrome : Caused by a gain-of-function mutation in the epithelial sodium channel (ENaC), leading to hypertension, hypokalemia, and metabolic alkalosis. It is unrelated to aquaporin function.
  • • Option A. Liddle's syndrome
  • • Option B. Nephrogenic DI : Results from mutations in the aquaporin-2 gene or the vasopressin V2 receptor gene, affecting water reabsorption in the kidneys. This is primarily a renal disorder and does not involve sweat glands.
  • • Option B. Nephrogenic DI
  • • Option D. Bartter syndrome : A renal tubular disorder due to mutations in transporters in the ascending loop of Henle, leading to hypokalemia, metabolic alkalosis, and salt-wasting. It is unrelated to aquaporins.
  • • Option D. Bartter syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Mutations in aquaporin genes can manifest differently depending on the specific aquaporin affected and the organ system involved. While aquaporin-2 mutations are linked to nephrogenic DI, other aquaporin mutations can affect sweat gland function, leading to conditions like hypohidrotic ectodermal dysplasia. Recognizing these distinct presentations is crucial for diagnosis and management.

References:

  • ↳ Reference

questions.text: Which of the following drugs used in the management of type 2 diabetes is associated with an increased risk of urinary tract infections? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Dapagliflozin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Dapagliflozin, an SGLT2 inhibitor, is associated with an increased risk of urinary tract infections due to its mechanism of increasing glucose excretion in the urine. This highlights the importance of monitoring for UTIs in patients prescribed this medication.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with a known history of diabetes mellitus presents with a BP of 150/90 and dizziness. What is the best way to manage this patient? ( INICET Nov 2023)
questions.correct_answer: D. Diet, Exercise, Lifestyle modification + Amlodipine
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Diet, Exercise, Lifestyle modification + Amlodipine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For hypertensive diabetic patients, it is essential to start pharmacological therapy along with lifestyle modifications to reduce cardiovascular risk. Amlodipine is an appropriate choice for initial therapy in this context.

questions.text: A woman presents with numbness of her fingertips. On examination, her face is tightened. The antinuclear antibody (ANA) is found to be positive and immunofluorescence shows the nucleolar pattern. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Systemic sclerosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Systemic sclerosis (scleroderma) is associated with positive ANA with a nucleolar pattern, skin tightening, and symptoms like Raynaud's phenomenon. This combination of clinical findings and specific antibody patterns helps in diagnosing systemic sclerosis.

questions.text: All of the following are criteria for diagnosis of DKA except: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) S. Potassium < 3.5 mEq/L

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The diagnostic criteria for DKA include hyperglycemia, ketosis, and metabolic acidosis with an increased anion gap. Potassium levels, while important to monitor and manage in DKA, are not part of the diagnostic criteria.

questions.text: A 22-year-old female patient came with complaints of vomiting and a decrease in movement of the right leg. In the past, she has had episodes of violent and aggressive behavior and abdominal pain. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Acute intermittent porphyria

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The acute intermittent porphyria presents with a complex array of symptoms, including neurological, gastrointestinal, and psychiatric manifestations, and is associated with specific triggers and a genetic basis. Elevated ALA and PBG levels during attacks are diagnostic.

questions.text: The production of which of the following hormones is increased in obesity? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Insulin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In obesity, insulin resistance occurring due defect at receptors which causes compensatory hyperinsulinemia. Thyroxine, growth hormone, and adiponectin have lipolytic effects, hence, their levels are reduced in obesity.

References:

  • ↳ Reference - Harrison/Obesity

questions.text: Cryoglobulinemia is associated with? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Hepatitis C

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Most common cause a/w Cryoglobulinemia is hepatitis C

questions.text: A ventrolateral cordotomy performed to alleviate pain in the right leg is effective because it interrupts which of the following? (NEET PG 2014)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • A ventrolateral cordotomy is a surgical procedure aimed at relieving pain by interrupting specific nerve pathways in the spinal cord. The lateral spinothalamic tract is primarily responsible for transmitting pain and temperature sensations from the body to the brain. In this pathway, nerve fibers from the right side of the body cross over to the left side of the spinal cord and ascend to the brain.
  • • When performing a ventrolateral cordotomy to alleviate pain in the right leg, the surgeon targets the left lateral spinothalamic tract. This is because the pain and temperature sensations from the right leg are transmitted through this tract on the left side of the spinal cord. By interrupting this tract, the transmission of pain signals from the right leg to the brain is blocked, thereby alleviating pain.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A . Left dorsal column: The dorsal columns are responsible for transmitting sensations of fine touch, vibration, and proprioception (position sense) rather than pain and temperature. Interrupting the left dorsal column would not effectively alleviate pain in the right leg.
  • • Option
  • • A
  • • Left dorsal column:
  • • Option C . Right lateral spinothalamic tract: The right lateral spinothalamic tract carries pain and temperature sensations from the left side of the body. Therefore, interrupting the right lateral spinothalamic tract would not affect pain sensations from the right leg.
  • • Option
  • • C
  • • Right lateral spinothalamic tract:
  • • Option D . Right corticospinal tract: The corticospinal tract is involved in motor control, carrying motor signals from the brain to the spinal cord and muscles. Interrupting the right corticospinal tract would result in motor deficits rather than alleviating pain in the right leg.
  • • Option
  • • D
  • • Right corticospinal tract:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A ventrolateral cordotomy to alleviate pain in the right leg is effective because it interrupts the left lateral spinothalamic tract, which carries pain and temperature sensations from the right side of the body to the brain.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man presented with back pain for the past 3 months. On examination, he has pallor, and gamma globulins are elevated. LFT is normal. X-ray spine shows multiple lytic lesions. Which of the following cells are involved in the pathogenesis of this patient's condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Plasma cells

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The patient's presentation is consistent with multiple myeloma , a plasma cell neoplasm. Key diagnostic features include:
  • • multiple myeloma
  • • Back pain: Common in multiple myeloma due to bone involvement. Pallor: Indicates anemia, a common finding in multiple myeloma. Elevated gamma globulins: Suggests a monoclonal protein spike (M spike) on serum protein electrophoresis. Multiple lytic lesions on X-ray: Classic radiographic finding in multiple myeloma due to bone destruction.
  • • Back pain: Common in multiple myeloma due to bone involvement.
  • • Back pain:
  • • Pallor: Indicates anemia, a common finding in multiple myeloma.
  • • Pallor:
  • • Elevated gamma globulins: Suggests a monoclonal protein spike (M spike) on serum protein electrophoresis.
  • • Elevated gamma globulins:
  • • Multiple lytic lesions on X-ray: Classic radiographic finding in multiple myeloma due to bone destruction.
  • • Multiple lytic lesions on X-ray:
  • • In multiple myeloma, malignant clonal plasma cells proliferate in the bone marrow, leading to the production of abnormal monoclonal immunoglobulins, bone destruction, and marrow infiltration.
  • • plasma cells
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A, B & D: Not primarily involved in multiple myeloma.
  • • Option A, B & D:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Multiple myeloma is a plasma cell neoplasm characterized by anemia, elevated gamma globulins, and lytic bone lesions, with plasma cells being the key pathological cells involved.

questions.text: A male patient presents with sensory loss and weakness of limbs for 3 months. He also has angular stomatitis. On examination, there is loss of proprioception, vibration sensations, UMN type of lower limb weakness, and absent ankle reflex. What is the most probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)

options.label: D
options.text: Subacute combined degeneration of the cord

questions.correct_answer: D. Subacute combined degeneration of the cord
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Subacute combined degeneration of the cord

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Subacute combined degeneration of the cord due to vitamin B12 deficiency presents with sensory loss, UMN signs in the lower limbs, and absent ankle reflex, along with other signs of vitamin deficiency like angular stomatitis.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man with a known history of DM and HTN on regular medications presents with a history of progressively worsening dyspnea on exertion. On examination, there is elevated JVP, positive hepatojugular reflux, crackles at the lung bases, hepatomegaly, ascites, and pedal oedema. What is your provisional diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Heart failure

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The constellation of symptoms such as elevated JVP, systemic edema (hepatomegaly, ascites, pedal edema), and pulmonary findings (crackles at the lung bases) strongly suggests heart failure, likely due to the patient's known history of hypertension and diabetes contributing to chronic cardiac stress and dysfunction.

References:

  • ↳ Reference - Harrison/Clinical Cardiology/Chap 239

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presented with proximal weakness, lethargy, low/depressed mood, and recurrent renal stones. Laboratory testing revealed a normal S. Calcium and increased PTH levels. What is the organ involved and the pathology? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Parathyroid gland and hyperparathyroidism

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Normocalcemic primary hyperparathyroidism presents with normal serum calcium and elevated PTH levels and is associated with symptoms like proximal weakness, lethargy, low mood, and recurrent renal stones. It is a diagnosis of exclusion after ruling out other causes of secondary hyperparathyroidism.

questions.text: Acid-base imbalance is suspected in a patient. Which of the following would you use to determine it? (INICET MAY 2021) Arterial pH Venous pH Venous pO2 Venous pCO2
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Arterial pH, venous pH, and venous pCO2 are used to determine acid-base imbalances.

questions.text: You are posted as an intern in casualty. An elderly 60-year-old man is brought to you with complaints of chest pain. He has tested positive for COVID. Which of the following features will prompt you to get this patient admitted to dedicated COVID health centre? (INICET NOV 2020) A. Respiratory rate of 25/min B. SpO2 93% C. Multiple comorbidities D. Age
questions.correct_answer: B. A, B, C & D only
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) A, B, C & D only

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ When evaluating a COVID-19 patient for hospital admission, consider clinical signs of respiratory distress, overall oxygen saturation, presence of comorbidities, and age due to their significant impacts on disease severity and outcome.

questions.text: Which of the following antiretroviral drugs is contraindicated in patients with HIV & hepatitis B co-infection due to the risk of severe exacerbation of HBV upon discontinuation? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Lamivudine

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Lamivudine, while effective against both HIV and HBV, is associated with a high rate of HBV resistance when used as monotherapy or in suboptimal combinations. Abrupt discontinuation of lamivudine in patients co-infected with HIV and HBV can lead to severe exacerbation of hepatitis B due to the rebound replication of HBV. Thus, lamivudine must always be used in combination with other HBV-active drugs to prevent resistance and rebound hepatitis.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Abacavir : Abacavir lacks efficacy against HBV and is not used in the treatment of HIV & HBV co-infection but is not directly contraindicated.
  • • Option B. Abacavir
  • • Option C. Tenofovir : Tenofovir has potent activity against both HIV and HBV and is a cornerstone of co-infection management.
  • • Option C. Tenofovir
  • • Option D. Emtricitabine : Emtricitabine is effective against both HIV and HBV, often used in combination with tenofovir to provide dual activity.
  • • Option D. Emtricitabine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lamivudine, though effective against HBV, carries a significant risk of resistance and rebound HBV replication upon discontinuation. For patients co-infected with HIV and HBV, combination therapy with tenofovir and emtricitabine is preferred to minimize resistance and prevent HBV flares.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child with AIDS presented with fever and productive cough. On auscultation, bronchial breath sounds and crepitations were heard in the right infra-scapular region. Chest X-ray showed right lower lobe consolidation. The CD4 count was 55 cells/mm3. What is the most common causative organism for this condition? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Streptococcus pneumoniae

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In patients with AIDS, Streptococcus pneumoniae remains the most common cause of bacterial pneumonia, regardless of the CD4 count. This should be a primary consideration when evaluating pneumonia in this population.

questions.text: Which of the following is a negative acute phase reactants ? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Albumin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: A patient presents with severe abdominal pain. Identify the false statement given about the examination of the abdomen: (INICET NOV 2022)

options.label: A
options.text: Hemoperitoneum leads to reddish discoloration of the flanks of the abdomen.

options.label: B
options.text: Cullen’s sign refers to discoloration around the umbilicus.

options.label: C
options.text: Palpation begins at the site of pain.

options.label: D
options.text: Guarding and rigidity indicate peritoneal irritation.

questions.correct_answer: C. Palpation begins at the site of pain.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Palpation begins at the site of pain.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ When examining a patient with abdominal pain, always begin palpation away from the site of pain to ensure a more accurate and less distressing assessment.

questions.text: Tongue fasciculations are seen in: ( INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tongue fasciculations are a clinical sign associated with spinal muscular atrophy due to the involvement of lower motor neurons

questions.text: A 62-year-old male patient with heart failure is scheduled for a heart transplant. His renal function test is deranged, and hemoglobin is 6 g/dL. The physician ordered 2 units of whole blood. Four hours after transfusion, he developed severe respiratory distress. On examination, he is hypoxemic, has tachycardia, and his mean arterial pressure is elevated. Which of the following are the best investigations for the above scenario? (INICET NOV 2021) Chest X-ray Brain natriuretic peptide (BNP) level Absolute neutrophil count Leucocyte antibodies Platelets
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 1 and 2

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For a patient with suspected transfusion-associated circulatory overload (TACO), the best investigations are a chest X-ray to detect pulmonary edema and BNP levels to assess cardiac stress and fluid overload

questions.text: An elderly diabetic and hypertensive patient was carried to the emergency room in a comatose state. On examination, the blood pressure was 170/100 mmHg and pulse rate were >100/min. Plantar reflex was bilateral extensor. What is the next step to do? ( AIIMS May 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Check Blood sugar level

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The initial management of any comatose patient, particularly those with diabetes, should include rapid assessment of blood glucose levels to rule out hypo- or hyperglycemia as a reversible cause of the coma. This immediate action can be life-saving and should precede other investigations and treatments.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient with bronchial asthma is currently on inhaler therapy with ipratropium and formoterol. Despite the medication, his symptoms are not improving due to hand-mouth incoordination. What should be the next step in management? (FMGE JULY 2024)

options.label: A
options.text: Add budesonide with monitoring of plasma levels of these drugs

options.label: B
options.text: Monitor plasma levels of ipratropium and formoterol

questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Use a spacer device

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For asthma patients with hand-mouth incoordination, using a spacer device is an effective solution to improve medication delivery and symptom control.

questions.text: A 22-year-old patient has fever with severe shortness of breath and red currant jelly sputum. On examination, he has altered sensorium with a respiratory rate of 35 breaths/min. Lab investigations show serum creatinine of 1.9 mg/dL. CXR is done and shows multi-lobar infiltrates. What is correct regarding the management? ( FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) ICU management (IV drugs)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • The patient presents with severe symptoms of community-acquired pneumonia, including fever, severe shortness of breath, red currant jelly sputum, altered sensorium, a high respiratory rate, and multi-lobar infiltrates on the chest X-ray.
  • • The CURB-65 score and IDSA/ATS guidelines for severe community-acquired pneumonia suggest that patients with severe symptoms, especially those meeting major criteria or multiple minor criteria, require intensive care unit (ICU) management.
  • • CURB-65 Criteria (score 0-5)
  • • CURB-65 Criteria (score 0-5)
  • • Confusion Uremia (BUN > 19 mg/dL or Urea >40 mg/dL) Respiratory rate ≥ 30/min Blood pressure (systolic < 90 mmHg or diastolic ≤ 60 mmHg) Age ≥ 65 years
  • • Confusion
  • • Uremia (BUN > 19 mg/dL or Urea >40 mg/dL)
  • • Respiratory rate ≥ 30/min
  • • Blood pressure (systolic < 90 mmHg or diastolic ≤ 60 mmHg)
  • • Age ≥ 65 years
  • • The patient scores high on these criteria due to confusion, high respiratory rate, and multi-lobar infiltrates.
  • • IDSA/ATS Criteria for Severe CAP
  • • IDSA/ATS Criteria for Severe CAP
  • • Minor Criteria
  • • Minor Criteria
  • • Respiratory rate ≥ 30 breaths/min PaO2/FiO2 ratio ≤ 250 Multi-lobar infiltrates Confusion/disorientation Uremia (BUN level ≥ 20 mg/dL) Leukopenia (WBC count < 4000 cells/mm3) Thrombocytopenia (platelet count < 100,000 cells/mm3) Hypothermia (core temperature < 36°C) Hypotension requiring aggressive fluid resuscitation
  • • Respiratory rate ≥ 30 breaths/min
  • • PaO2/FiO2 ratio ≤ 250
  • • Multi-lobar infiltrates
  • • Confusion/disorientation
  • • Uremia (BUN level ≥ 20 mg/dL)
  • • Leukopenia (WBC count < 4000 cells/mm3)
  • • Thrombocytopenia (platelet count < 100,000 cells/mm3)
  • • Hypothermia (core temperature < 36°C)
  • • Hypotension requiring aggressive fluid resuscitation
  • • Major Criteria
  • • Major Criteria
  • • Septic shock requiring vasopressors Respiratory failure requiring mechanical ventilation
  • • Septic shock requiring vasopressors
  • • Respiratory failure requiring mechanical ventilation
  • • The patient meets several minor criteria, indicating severe CAP requiring ICU admission and intravenous antibiotics.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. OPD management: Not appropriate for severe symptoms and high CURB-65 score.
  • • Option A. OPD management:
  • • Option B. IPD management: While necessary, ICU care is more appropriate.
  • • Option B. IPD management:
  • • Option C. ICU management (oral drugs): IV drugs are required for severe cases in the ICU.
  • • Option C. ICU management (oral drugs):

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Patients with severe community-acquired pneumonia, especially those with altered sensorium, high respiratory rate, and multi-lobar infiltrates, should be managed in the ICU with intravenous antibiotics.

questions.text: Which of the following does not show both hyperkinetic and hypokinetic movements? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Huntington's chorea primarily presents with hyperkinetic movements and not hypokinetic movements.

questions.text: A patient with a history of chronic liver disease presents with abdominal distension, jaundice, and pruritis. Ascitic fluid analysis revealed a neutrophil count > 650 per cubic mm. What is the most likely diagnosis? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Spontaneous bacterial peritonitis should be suspected in patients with chronic liver disease and ascites if the ascitic fluid neutrophil count exceeds 250 cells/mm3, necessitating prompt antibiotic treatment.

questions.text: Deep y descent in Jugular Venous Pressure (JVP) is seen in all of the following conditions except: (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Cardiac Tamponade

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ In cardiac tamponade, the presence of fluid in the pericardial space restricts all phases of cardiac filling, leading to a blunted or absent y descent, differentiating it from conditions where a deep y descent is observed.

questions.text: A young child presented with nocturnal chest pain and a history of syncope has the ECG shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis? ( INICET Nov 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Brugada syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Brugada syndrome should be suspected in patients, especially young males, with a history of syncope or nocturnal chest pain presenting with the characteristic ECG pattern of pseudo-right bundle branch block and ST-segment elevation in leads V1 and V2.

questions.text: A patient presents with sudden onset of chest pain, ST-segment elevation in leads V1-V3 on ECG, and polymorphic ventricular tachycardia. Genetic testing reveals a loss-of-function mutation in the SCN5A gene. What is the most likely diagnosis? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Brugada syndrome

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Brugada syndrome is a genetic disorder caused by a loss-of-function mutation in the SCN5A gene , which encodes the sodium channel responsible for the cardiac action potential. It is characterized by:
  • • Brugada syndrome
  • • loss-of-function mutation in the SCN5A gene
  • • ECG findings: ST-segment elevation in the right precordial leads (V1-V3). Arrhythmias: A predisposition to polymorphic ventricular tachycardia and sudden cardiac death. Pathophysiology: A transmural voltage difference between the endocardium and epicardium of the right ventricle due to altered sodium channel function. Diagnosis: Based on characteristic ECG changes, clinical presentation, and genetic testing. Management: Implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD) for high-risk patients and avoidance of fever and certain medications that exacerbate the condition.
  • • ECG findings: ST-segment elevation in the right precordial leads (V1-V3).
  • • ECG findings:
  • • Arrhythmias: A predisposition to polymorphic ventricular tachycardia and sudden cardiac death.
  • • Arrhythmias:
  • • Pathophysiology: A transmural voltage difference between the endocardium and epicardium of the right ventricle due to altered sodium channel function.
  • • Pathophysiology:
  • • Diagnosis: Based on characteristic ECG changes, clinical presentation, and genetic testing.
  • • Diagnosis:
  • • Management: Implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD) for high-risk patients and avoidance of fever and certain medications that exacerbate the condition.
  • • Management:
  • • Incorrect Options:
  • • Incorrect Options:
  • • Option A. Takotsubo cardiomyopathy: Incorrect because Takotsubo cardiomyopathy involves apical ballooning and ECG findings that mimic myocardial infarction but does not typically cause polymorphic ventricular tachycardia or mutations in SCN5A.
  • • Option A. Takotsubo cardiomyopathy:
  • • Option B. Restrictive cardiomyopathy: Incorrect because restrictive cardiomyopathy involves diastolic dysfunction and does not present with ventricular arrhythmias or ST-segment elevation on ECG.
  • • Option B. Restrictive cardiomyopathy:
  • • Option D. Pericardial tamponade: Incorrect because tamponade causes Beck’s triad (hypotension, muffled heart sounds, and raised JVP) and electrical alternans on ECG, not ST-segment elevation or ventricular arrhythmias.
  • • Option D. Pericardial tamponade:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Brugada syndrome should be suspected in patients with characteristic ECG findings (ST-segment elevation in V1-V3), ventricular arrhythmias, and genetic mutations like SCN5A. Early identification is critical to prevent sudden cardiac death through appropriate management, including ICD placement.

questions.text: A hypertensive patient who is on losartan develops an HbA1c level of 8.1%. Which of the following drugs would you replace losartan with? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Telmisartan

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For hypertensive patients with diabetes and elevated HbA1c levels, Telmisartan is the preferred replacement for losartan due to its PPAR-gamma agonistic activity, which helps improve glycemic control.

questions.text: Identify the clinical diagnosis: (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Plexiform neurofibromatosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Plexiform neurofibromatosis should be suspected in patients with extensive, soft, non-tender, and irregularly contoured masses along nerve pathways, particularly in those known to have or suspected of having NF1. Surgical resection can be considered for symptomatic relief or cosmetic reasons, though complete removal is often challenging due to the nature of the growth

questions.text: A mutation in the gene for aquaporin channel leads to which of the following conditions? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Nephrogenic DI

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A mutation in the aquaporin channels, particularly Aquaporin-2, leads to nephrogenic diabetes insipidus. This condition is characterized by an inability of the kidneys to concentrate urine in response to ADH, resulting in the production of large volumes of dilute urine. Understanding the genetic basis of nephrogenic DI is crucial for accurate diagnosis and management, which typically involves addressing the symptoms and managing water intake rather than hormone therapy.

References:

  • ↳ Reference - Harrison/Diabetes Insipidus/Chapter 381

questions.text: In the context of cardiac examination, Erb's point corresponds to which of the following locations? (NEET PG 2015)

options.label: A
options.text: The second intercostal space on the right side

options.label: B
options.text: The second intercostal space on the left side

options.label: C
options.text: The third intercostal space on the right side

options.label: D
options.text: The third intercostal space on the left side

questions.correct_answer: D. The third intercostal space on the left side
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Erb's point is anatomically located at the third intercostal space on the left side of the sternum. This is an important auscultatory area during cardiac examination as multiple murmurs may be heard at this location. The third left intercostal space is a significant area where sounds from different cardiac structures converge, making it a crucial point for clinical examination of the heart.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. The second intercostal space on the right side : This is the aortic area of cardiac auscultation where aortic valve sounds and murmurs related to the aortic valve are best heard. It is not Erb's point.
  • • Option A. The second intercostal space on the right side
  • • Option B. The second intercostal space on the left side : This is the pulmonic area where pulmonic valve sounds and murmurs associated with the pulmonary valve are best heard. This is not Erb's point.
  • • Option B. The second intercostal space on the left side
  • • Option C. The third intercostal space on the right side : This is not a standard auscultatory area for cardiac examination. Erb's point is specifically on the left side, not the right.
  • • Option C. The third intercostal space on the right side

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Erb's point is located at the third intercostal space on the left side of the sternum and serves as an important auscultatory area where multiple cardiac murmurs may be detected during examination.

questions.text: A woman presents with recurrent episodes of gross hematuria, which often follow upper respiratory tract infections. She has no systemic symptoms such as fever or arthralgia. Urine examination reveals RBC casts and mild proteinuria. What is the likely diagnosis? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • IgA nephropathy is the most common glomerulonephritis worldwide and typically presents with recurrent episodes of gross hematuria. Key features include:
  • • IgA nephropathy
  • • Association with infections: Hematuria often occurs shortly after upper respiratory tract infections due to abnormal IgA deposition in the glomeruli. Urine findings: RBC casts and mild proteinuria indicate glomerular damage. Lack of systemic symptoms: Unlike lupus nephritis, IgA nephropathy does not present with systemic symptoms such as fever or arthralgia.
  • • Association with infections: Hematuria often occurs shortly after upper respiratory tract infections due to abnormal IgA deposition in the glomeruli.
  • • Association with infections:
  • • Urine findings: RBC casts and mild proteinuria indicate glomerular damage.
  • • Urine findings:
  • • Lack of systemic symptoms: Unlike lupus nephritis, IgA nephropathy does not present with systemic symptoms such as fever or arthralgia.
  • • Lack of systemic symptoms:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Acute interstitial nephritis: Incorrect because AIN usually presents with sterile pyuria, WBC casts, and systemic signs of hypersensitivity, such as rash and fever, not recurrent hematuria.
  • • Option A. Acute interstitial nephritis:
  • • Option B. Poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis: Incorrect because PSGN typically presents weeks after a streptococcal infection, with cola-colored urine, RBC casts, and systemic findings like edema and hypertension.
  • • Option B. Poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis:
  • • Option C. Lupus nephritis: Incorrect because lupus nephritis is associated with systemic lupus erythematosus and systemic symptoms such as fever, arthralgia, and fatigue, which are not present in this case.
  • • Option C. Lupus nephritis:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ IgA nephropathy should be suspected in patients with recurrent gross hematuria following infections and no systemic symptoms. The presence of RBC casts and mild proteinuria supports a glomerular etiology. Early diagnosis is crucial to monitor for potential progression to chronic kidney disease.

questions.text: A person comes to the OPD with symptoms of not using his left side and not washing the left side of his body while bathing. On examination he wasn't able to draw the left side of the images. Which of the following is the most likely location of the lesion? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Right posterior parietal area

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Left-sided neglect is often due to a lesion in the right posterior parietal area.

questions.text: A female patient with infertility presents with galactorrhea. Evaluation reveals a 7mm prolactinoma. She is worried about her conception chances. What is the appropriate drug in this situation? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Although cabergoline is often used for prolactinomas due to better tolerability and efficacy, it is not the preferred agent when fertility is desired, especially around the time of conception or planned pregnancy.
  • • According to endocrine guidelines:
  • • According to endocrine guidelines:
  • • Bromocriptine has been safely used for over 30 years in women trying to conceive, with no proven teratogenicity.
  • • Once pregnancy is confirmed, bromocriptine is discontinued to reduce fetal exposure.
  • • Cabergoline, being long-acting with high D₂ receptor affinity, is not recommended during conception planning, due to less extensive safety data in pregnancy.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Cabergoline : Not preferred in women desiring fertility due to longer half-life and limited pregnancy safety data.
  • • Option A. Cabergoline
  • • Option C. Octreotide : A somatostatin analog used for GH-secreting tumors (e.g., acromegaly), not prolactinomas.
  • • Option C. Octreotide
  • • Option D. Pegvisomant : GH receptor antagonist for acromegaly; no role in prolactinoma or fertility.
  • • Option D. Pegvisomant

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In women with microprolactinoma and infertility, bromocriptine is the first-line treatment to restore ovulation and promote safe conception. While cabergoline is effective and often better tolerated, it is not the agent of choice when pregnancy is desired, due to concerns regarding its longer action and limited pregnancy safety data.

questions.text: A Patient came with sudden onset palpitations. ECG showed narrow complex, regular tachycardia without P waves, and a rate of 160bpm. His BP is 96/68mmHg. What is the next step in management? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Carotid sinus massage.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Carotid sinus massage is the first-line intervention for clinically stable patients presenting with AVNRT, potentially stopping the arrhythmia without the need for drug intervention.

questions.text: Samter’s triad refers to the association of Aspirin-sensitive asthma and: (NEET PG 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Nasal polyp

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Samter's triad (also called AERD - Aspirin Exacerbated Respiratory Disease) consists of nasal polyps, bronchial asthma, and aspirin hypersensitivity. This classic triad represents a specific phenotype of asthma that often presents with severe symptoms and can be challenging to manage due to the multiple body systems involved and the potential for severe reactions to NSAIDs.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Obesity : While obesity can be associated with asthma and may contribute to its severity, it is not a component of Samter's triad. Obesity is a risk factor for OSA and can worsen asthma control, but it's not part of this specific syndrome.
  • • Option A. Obesity
  • • Option B. Urticaria : Urticaria (hives) is not part of Samter's triad. While aspirin sensitivity can sometimes cause urticaria in some patients, it's not a defining feature of Samter's triad which specifically involves the respiratory tract.
  • • Option B. Urticaria
  • • Option D. Rhinosinusitis : While patients with Samter's triad frequently have chronic rhinosinusitis, the specific defining feature mentioned in the triad is nasal polyps, not rhinosinusitis itself. Nasal polyps represent a more specific pathological finding.
  • • Option D. Rhinosinusitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Samter's triad is the specific association of three clinical entities: nasal polyps, bronchial asthma, and aspirin hypersensitivity, representing a distinct clinical syndrome requiring specific management considerations.

questions.text: Which of the following are true regarding KF ring? (INICET NOV 2020) 1. Seen in all patients with neurological involvement 2. Is pathognomonic for Wilson's disease 3. Resolves with desferrioxamine 4. Seen in all patients with hepatic involvement 5. Seen in superior and inferior pole of Descemet's membrane
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 1 and 5 only.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ KF can be seen in disorders causing chronic cholestasis. Seen in ~99% of patients with neuro wilson's, 44-60% with hepatic involvement.
  • ➤ Desferioxamine is chelating agent in iron toxicity.

References:

  • ↳ Reference - Harrison/Liver/Wilsons/Chap 344

questions.text: For the diagnosis of resistant hypertension, the patient should have uncontrolled hypertension despite taking three antihypertensive drugs. This should include at least one? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The diagnostic criteria for resistant hypertension include having blood pressure above target despite taking three drugs, one of which must be a diuretic, OR having controlled blood pressure with four or more drugs. Typically, a thiazide diuretic is used in the setting of hypertension.

questions.text: A patient presents with a seizure. On evaluation, urine osmolality is 1000 mOsm/Kg and serum osmolality is 270 mOsm/Kg. Which electrolyte abnormality can be expected in this patient? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Hyponatremia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In patients presenting with low serum osmolality and high urine osmolality, SIADH is a likely diagnosis, and the primary electrolyte abnormality to expect is hyponatremia.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of mortality in DKA? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cerebral edema is the most common cause of mortality in diabetic ketoacidosis, especially during the treatment phase when rapid shifts in osmolality occur.

questions.text: The serum electrolyte values of a patient weighing 60 kg are given below. Calculate the sodium deficit in the patient. pH: 7.42, Na+: 120 mEq/L, serum K+: 4 mEq/L, serum CI-: 90 mEq/L? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sodium deficit -
  • ➤ Sodium deficit -
  • ➤ Rate of Correction : It's critical to correct chronic hyponatremia slowly to avoid complications like osmotic demyelination syndrome. The recommended rate of correction should not exceed 6-8 mEq/L per day.
  • ➤ Rate of Correction
  • ➤ Monitoring : Frequent monitoring of serum sodium levels is necessary during the correction phase to adjust the treatment as needed and prevent overcorrection.
  • ➤ Monitoring
  • ➤ Ref: Harrison 21/Fluid and electrolyte/Chap 53
  • ➤ Ref: Harrison 21/Fluid and electrolyte/Chap 53

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presented with weight gain, proximal muscle weakness, purple striae, and easy bruising. What is the likely underlying condition? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Hypercortisolism

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cushing's syndrome, or hypercortisolism, is characterized by weight gain, proximal muscle weakness, purple striae, and easy bruising due to the catabolic effects of excess cortisol.

questions.text: A female patient presents to you with a unilateral headache. It is associated with nausea, photophobia, and phonophobia. What is the best drug for acute management? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sumatriptan is the drug of choice for the acute management of moderate to severe migraine attacks due to its vasoconstrictive properties and effectiveness in rapidly alleviating migraine symptoms.

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient presented with low-grade fever and cough. Chest X-ray is shown. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Miliary TB

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Miliary tuberculosis should be suspected in patients with low-grade fever, cough, and a chest X-ray showing multiple small nodules throughout the lung fields, especially in regions with high tuberculosis prevalence.

questions.text: A patient came with complaints of high-grade fever & altered sensorium. He was diagnosed to be suffering from meningococcal meningitis. Which of the following is the most appropriate empirical treatment? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Ceftriaxone

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ceftriaxone is the preferred empirical therapy for meningococcal meningitis due to its effective CNS penetration, broad antibacterial coverage, and favorable dosing regimen. Immediate initiation of empirical therapy is crucial in suspected bacterial meningitis to prevent severe outcomes.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female patient came with complaints of chest pain, palpitation, and shortness of breath. On examination, a mid-diastolic murmur was heard, and a prominent 'a' wave was found on JVP. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Tricuspid stenosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A prominent 'a' wave in JVP and a mid-diastolic murmur are indicative of tricuspid stenosis, a condition causing right ventricular inflow obstruction.
